diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may lead to symptoms like chronic back pain and can indirectly affect sleep patterns, causing insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, which can lead to lymphadenopathy and chronic back pain.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which can lead to lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), lymphadenitis (infection of the lymph nodes), and potentially cause systemic symptoms like insomnia and back pain.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a narrowing, blockage, or the weakening of blood vessels, potentially leading to aneurysms. It can also cause general systemic symptoms like chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, this infectious disease is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It can cause lymphadenopathy, lymphadenitis, and has been known to contribute to chronic fatigue, which may be linked to insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system. It can lead to symptoms like swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), systemic symptoms, including fatigue which can be linked to insomnia, and generalized pain.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can cause some of the vertebrae in your spine to fuse together. This can lead to chronic back pain, and possibly impact sleep quality, leading to insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to chronic inflammation of joints and surrounding tissues, which can contribute to systemic symptoms like chronic back pain and fatigue, which in turn may affect sleep patterns.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue or tiredness that doesn’t go away with rest and can't be explained by an underlying medical condition. It may be speculated to have links with immune system dysfunction, potentially leading to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous symptoms, including painful mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation inside the eye, and vascular system involvement that can lead to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes is a common cause of gastroparesis and can also contribute to blood pressure lability and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.reasoning: Scleroderma can cause gastroparesis due to gut motility issues, joint pain, and eye irritation due to Sicca syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can slow down the digestive system leading to gastroparesis, and is also associated with joint pain and blood pressure irregularities.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune conditions, such as Rheumatoid Arthritis and Lupus, can cause joint pain, and scleroderma (another autoimmune disorder) can lead to gastroparesis and eye irritation.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Parkinson's Disease affects the autonomic nervous system and can cause gastroparesis, blood pressure lability, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Primary Amyloidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition can lead to gastroparesis due to deposits in gastrointestinal nerves, joint pain, and blood pressure lability due to autonomic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare condition that affects the autonomic nervous system, leading to gastroparesis and blood pressure lability, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Intestinal Pseudo-obstruction
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition mimics the symptoms of a bowel obstruction (such as gastroparesis) without any physical blockage and can be associated with autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Connective Tissue Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Diseases like Lupus and Sjögren's syndrome can cause joint pain and eye irritation. Gastroparesis may occur in advanced or severe cases due to autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.reasoning: Conditions leading to peripheral neuropathy, such as diabetes and autoimmune disorders, can cause gastroparesis by affecting the vagus nerve, and may also cause joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and dry mouth, which could indirectly lead to blepharospasm due to eye irritation and possibly gastroparesis due to autonomic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: A rare condition that affects the stomach and small intestine, can cause gastroparesis, and might be associated with leukocytosis due to an increase in eosinophils, a type of white blood cell.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and organ damage, presenting with symptoms that can include leukocytosis and potentially leading to complications like interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that often affects the lungs but can impact other areas like the eyes, leading to blepharospasm, and has been linked with leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can be very diverse, often including autonomic dysfunctions like gastroparesis and bladder problems similar to interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A condition where protein deposits, called amyloids, accumulate in organs and tissues. It can lead to gastroparesis due to involvement of the digestive tract and might be related to leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Primary immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: A disorder where the immune system is missing or not working properly, potentially leading to leukocytosis and making the body more susceptible to infections that could present as post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, including the eyes (potentially leading to blepharospasm) and possibly the digestive system, affecting motility akin to gastroparesis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurological conditions
diagnoses.description: Certain neurological disorders can cause gastroparesis due to involvement of the nervous system regulating the digestive tract, and conditions like Bell's palsy might also indirectly cause blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, potentially leading to gastroparesis, bladder dysfunction similar to interstitial cystitis, and systemic issues like leukocytosis.

diagnoses: Bleeding Disorders such as von Willebrand Disease

diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, decreased libido, and difficulty focusing which cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition.
A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Can manifest physically as fatigue, difficulty focusing, and decreased libido.
An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause fatigue, decreased libido, and lymphadenitis.
A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, depressed mood, and sometimes difficulty focusing.
An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth, fatigue, and joint pain, among other symptoms. It could contribute to difficulty focusing and decreased libido.
A chronic condition characterized by widespread pain, fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. May also lead to symptoms like difficulty focusing and decreased libido.
Human immunodeficiency virus is a virus that can lead to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, or AIDS. Among various symptoms, patients may experience fatigue, lymphadenitis, and decreased libido.
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms include fatigue, difficulty with vision focusing, and sometimes sexual dysfunction.

An autoimmune disease characterized by systemic inflammation affecting multiple organs, including possible kidney involvement (interstitial nephritis) which might be confused with interstitial cystitis. Symptoms include fatigue and lymphadenitis.
A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar, which over time can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, and indirectly affect vision and sexual function.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

Also known as classic migraine, involves neurological phenomena (aura) that precedes the headache. The aura can include visual disturbances, such as flashes of light or blind spots, or other disturbances such as sensory, motor, or verbal disturbances.
The most common type of headache among adults and teens. These headaches cause mild to moderate pain and come and go over time. They usually have no other symptoms.
Severe headaches that occur in clusters or cyclical patterns. These headaches are typically very painful and occur on one side of the head, often accompanied by watery eyes and nasal congestion.

Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It doesn't cause lasting damage. Symptoms can include weakness, loss of vision or double vision, and speech difficulties.

A medical condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headaches, confusion, trouble speaking and understanding speech, and paralysis or numbness of the face, arms, or legs.

A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS blocks the messages that flow between the brain and the body, often leading to muscle weakness, imbalance, or problems with coordination and vision.
A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.
A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Meniere's disease affects only one ear.
An inflammatory disease affecting the large blood vessels of the scalp, neck, and arms. It causes headaches, jaw pain, and impaired vision, which can be sudden.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain accompanied by visual disturbances, sensitivity to sound (phonophobia), and sometimes nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Basilar-Type Migraine
diagnoses.description: A migraine variant that involves the brainstem, presenting with aura symptoms including visual disturbances (scotoma), speech disturbances (aphasia), and often includes severe headache, nausea, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where individuals experience a migraine with aura that includes temporary paralysis (hemiplegia) or neurological or sensory changes on one side of the body, along with visual disturbances, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and possibly vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing symptoms such as difficulty speaking (aphasia), visual problems (including scotoma), and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA presents with short-lived (less than 24 hours) neurologic dysfunction due to focal brain ischemia, including symptoms like aphasia, visual disturbances, and occasional headache.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound (phonophobia).

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause pressure effects including headache, nausea, vomiting, aphasia, and visual disturbances depending on the tumor location.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can mirror those of brain tumors, including headaches, nausea, vomiting, aphasia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness, with some types possibly presenting with headache, visual disturbances, and postictal confusion including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels that can cause headaches, visual disturbances, jaw pain, and occasionally symptoms including vomiting and visual loss.

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., viral or bacterial infections causing pericarditis)
Tuberculosis (particularly in regions where it is endemic)
Bacterial infections (e.g., severe bacterial infections leading to septicemia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Discoid rash and proteinuria are characteristic of SLE, and patients may also experience neurological symptoms such as delirium. Nasal ulcers could also be associated with this condition.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily associated with muscle weakness and skin rashes, some of the described symptoms could overlap in atypical presentations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can present with features of several diseases including lupus. Symptom overlap makes it a differential diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Known for causing dryness of mouth and eyes, but can also cause systemic issues and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily a joint disorder, systemic manifestations can include skin changes and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that involve inflammation of blood vessels. Nasal ulceration and skin findings might be present.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though typically associated with psoriasis and joint problems, systemic features can overlap with the mentioned symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This multiorgan disease can present with a wide range of symptoms including skin lesions and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Known for causing oral and genital ulcers, but it can also present with skin lesions and has been associated with neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although part of systemic lupus erythematosus, when presenting prominently with proteinuria, it deserves distinctive mention. The condition specifically affects the kidneys but is part of the systemic involvement of SLE.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Infectious diseases (such as tuberculosis, viral infections)
